home.title: Home | Open Summer of Code
home.wellcome1: Welcome to Open Summer of Code
home.wellcome2: Training programme for open source and innovation fans.
home.descwhat: A four-week programme that helps students from Spanish universities develop innovation projects for companies and organisations to transform them in useful services for our society.

agenda.title: Agenda | Open Summer of Code
agenda.wellcome1: Open Summer of Code is thought for any motivated, enthusiastic and talented person. Don't be shy, apply!

item1.name: Online edition presentation
item1.description: The online edition proposal of the oSoc will be presented, as the planned face-to-face edition is impossible.

item2.name: Opening
item2.description: For two weeks, from July 5 to 16, the online edition of the oSoc 2020 will take place.

item3.name: Demo Day
item3.description: On the 16th there will be an open exhibition of the work done in what we call Demo Day.

intro.p1: Due to the situation that is being experienced around the world by the Coronavirus crisis, Open Summer of Code 2020 Special Edition pose to students a series of challenges associated with the 'Day After': What will happen when people can go out again from their houses? What have we learned and how should we take it into account and apply them to our day to day (pollution, climate change...)?, what should our problems be from now on: science or soccer?
intro.p2: At Open Summer of Code we believe and are committed to digital innovation with social impact, we are changers of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and the 2030 agenda is promoting acceleration towards a better world that must change now. That is why we propose 3 projects (challenges) with this approach in which students can participate and collaborate guided by a mentor:

card1.title: HIGH QUALITY OPEN DATA IN MADRID
card1.description: This project proposes the implementation of a system to analyze and validate the quality of geographic data in CSV of the Madrid open data portal. It will make use of semantic technologies (SPARQL for queries, CSV on the Web for metadata) and is expected to be implemented in Python. The tool will be accompanied by a simple web application to facilitate its use by the end user.

card2.title: LATERALITY
card2.description:
Laterality is a disorder in which children do not have a defined dominant side in the brain, which produces a series of difficulties in learning from reading problems to pronunciation problems. 
 This project proposes to build a mobile application to help, through a series of exercises, children with difficulties in the pronunciation of the trabadas. Trabadas are those words that contain syllables with two consonants followed by a vowel. The application will have a series of levels through which the student will go through.

card3.title: HIRE A SENIOR
card3.description: Growing older should not be an obstacle when it’s time to perform an activity that you like, allows you to remain active and with which you feel fulfilled. The idea of this project is to develop an app focused on hiring retired people who are interested, so that they can continue to perform useful tasks and remain mentally active, and at the same time get an additional contribution to their pension. In addition, this will allow those interested in hiring, to have people with great experience in their staff.

inscription.title: Registration | Open Summer of Code
inscription.msg: Registration for oSoc 2020 is now open: goto inscription;

faq.title: FAQ  | Open Summer of Code
faq.subtitle: Because there are no such things as silly questions.

general.a1: Yes, oSoc 2021 will be online. This is how we have designed it. Participants must be virtually present (slack, skype, etc.) in order to take part in the proposed projects. We’ll schedule daily calls to organize the work, update on the progress, chat amongst the participants and ask any doubt we may have. During the day, the members of each team, including coaches, will be online for any doubt or project-specific comment.
general.a2: Yes. It’s intended to put in practice the knowledge acquired at the university. You’ll learn to manage and develop the proposed project and test your skills. You’ll also have a coach that will guide your training during the whole programme.
general.a3: #oSoc21 is a summer school where you can test your skills. It’s thought for students with different backgrounds to participate in the same project, interchanging experience and knowledge, applying it to the challenge we have designed this year.
general.q4: Which is my commitment when applying to #oSoc21?
general.a4: When the students apply, they are committed to participate in the development of the project under the conditions of the previously signed agreement. In fact, #oSoc21 helps students expand their contact network, acquire experience in multidisciplinary projects and learn from the coaches’ skills.
general.q5: Will the design and the code developed by students belong to the UPM?
general.a5: No. The development is open source. Both the design and the code belong to everyone.
general.q6: Where can I find information about #oSoc21? How can I explain #oSoc21 to my university partners?
general.a6: We have more information on our website https://summerofcode.es/ and social networks! We’ve recently opened an Instagram profile in which we’ll inform about the preparations of this year’s edition: https://www.instagram.com/osocode_es. Our Twitter account is https://twitter.com/oSocode_es (please RT!) and our Facebook profile is https://fb.me/oSocodees. Join our informative sessions too!
general.q7: Can I be student and coach of #oSoc21?
general.a7: They are different profiles, but some “advanced students” (if they have finished their studies and have some professional experience) can also be “coaches” of a team. The students will be part of the assigned team –they’ll be informed before the programme starts– and the coaches are experts that will guide each team during the whole #oSoc21, giving specific attention to their teams.
general.q8: Can I contact #oSoc21 if I have more doubts?
general.a8: Yes. Use our e-mail address osocspain@gmail.com whenever you have something to ask. Don’t think twice!
general.q9: Which are the most relevant changes regarding previous editions?
general.a9: We’ve designed a challenge that will be core idea of every project developed during #oSoc21. Initially, each participant chooses a proposal. Then, we’ll have a brainstorming stage to define more details of each project. The final day of the programme we’ll celebratethe Demo Day to expose the results of our projects.
general.a10: This year’s edition will exceptionally be two weeks long: from the 5th to the 16th of July.
general.a11: Considering the exceptional situation brought by the Covid-19 crisis, we don’t have funding companies behind our projects, so the participation is voluntary.
